title: Fairy Vearth is Actually a Sunken Continent, Not the Moon
theory: Some fans theorize that the 'Fairy Vearth' Enel seeks isn't actually the moon (where he eventually goes), but rather a sunken continent connected to the Ancient Kingdom. This theory suggests that the moon was a secondary destination and that the true 'endless earth' refers to lost landmasses beneath the sea, potentially connecting to the broader mysteries of the Void Century and the fall of the Ancient Kingdom.
author: Worstgen Forum Users

title: Enel Will Return in the Final Saga
theory: Based on Enel's revelation of his Fairy Vearth plan in this episode and his eventual journey to the moon, fans theorize that Enel will return during One Piece's final saga. The theory suggests that his knowledge of moon technology, ancient automata, and his lightning powers will make him relevant to endgame conflicts. Some speculate he could even become an ally against a greater threat, or that his moon discoveries contain crucial information about the Void Century.
author: Multiple Fan Communities

title: Enel's Heart Restart Technique Foreshadows Advanced Medical Applications
theory: Fans have theorized that Enel's ability to restart his own heart using electrical defibrillation (revealed in the next episode but set up here) demonstrates a level of biological knowledge that could have broader implications. Some speculate this technique could be connected to Vegapunk's research or could explain how certain characters survive seemingly fatal injuries. The theory extends to suggest that electricity manipulation might play a role in life-extension or resurrection technologies in the One Piece world.
author: Various Theorists

title: The Shandia's 800-Year Duty Connects to Joy Boy's Promise
theory: The flashback in this episode revealing the Shandia's 800-year duty to protect the Poneglyph has led fans to theorize a direct connection to Joy Boy and the promise made during the Void Century. Some theorists suggest that the message on the Shandora Poneglyph is specifically meant for someone who will come in the future (potentially Luffy), and that the Shandia's generational sacrifice is part of a larger plan set in motion by the Ancient Kingdom.
author: One Piece Theory Community

title: Enel's God Complex Parallels Real-World Tyranny Themes
theory: This episode's revelation of Enel's plan to destroy Skypiea because 'people living in the sky is unnatural' has led to discussions about the story's commentary on tyranny and the abuse of power. Fans theorize that Enel represents a critique of leaders who commit atrocities while claiming divine authority or natural order as justification. The theory extends to suggest that Oda is making broader statements about religious extremism and the danger of absolute power throughout the Skypiea arc.
author: One Piece Analysis Community
